discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
Answer C. By running your machine learning (ML) training job in a custom container, you can use ML frameworks, non-ML dependencies, libraries, and binaries that are not otherwise supported on Vertex AI. 
Model and your data are too large to fit in memory on a single machine hence distributed training jobs.
https://cloud.google.com/vertex-ai/docs/training/containers-overview

Selected Answer: C
C) Distributed training with customer containers

Selected Answer: C
This allows using external dependences and distributed training will solve the memory issues

Selected Answer: C
Critical dependencies that are not supported -> Custom container
Too large to fit in memory on a single machine -> Distributed

Selected Answer: C
Went with C

ans: C

B => discarded because "model and your data are too large to fit in memory on a single machine"

Will go for 'C'- Custom containers can address the env limitation and distributed processing will handle the data volume

choices.A: Use a built-in model available on AI Platform Training.
choices.B: Build your custom container to run jobs on AI Platform Training.
choices.D: Reconfigure your code to a ML framework with dependencies that are supported by AI Platform Training.
choices.C: Build your custom containers to run distributed training jobs on AI Platform Training.

questions.question_text: You recently designed and built a custom neural network that uses critical dependencies specific to your organization’s framework. You need to train the model using a managed training service on Google Cloud. However, the ML framework and related dependencies are not supported by AI Platform Training. Also, both your model and your data are too large to fit in memory on a single machine. Your ML framework of choice uses the scheduler, workers, and servers distribution structure. What should you do?

choices.D: Add parallel interleave to the pipeline

questions.question_text: While monitoring your model training’s GPU utilization, you discover that you have a native synchronous implementation. The training data is split into multiple files. You want to reduce the execution time of your input pipeline. What should you do?

questions.question_text: Your data science team is training a PyTorch model for image classification based on a pre-trained RestNet model. You need to perform hyperparameter tuning to optimize for several parameters. What should you do?

choices.B: Run a hyperparameter tuning job on AI Platform using custom containers.
choices.D: Convert the model to a TensorFlow model, and run a hyperparameter tuning job on AI Platform.
choices.C: Create a Kuberflow Pipelines instance, and run a hyperparameter tuning job on Katib.
choices.A: Convert the model to a Keras model, and run a Keras Tuner job.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
ans: B

A => no, you need customization.
C, B => more work and complexity

B => AutoML is easier and faster and "you need to quickly build, test, and deploy". Also the REST API part fits our use case.

Selected Answer: B
B) AutoML NLP

choices.D: Create a TensorFlow model using Google’s BERT pre-trained model. Build and test a classifier, and deploy the model using Vertex AI.
choices.C: Use BigQuery ML to build and test a logistic regression model to classify incoming requests. Use BigQuery ML to perform inference.
choices.A: Use the Cloud Natural Language API to obtain metadata to classify the incoming cases.
choices.B: Use AutoML Natural Language to build and test a classifier. Deploy the model as a REST API.

questions.question_text: You have a large corpus of written support cases that can be classified into 3 separate categories: Technical Support, Billing Support, or Other Issues. You need to quickly build, test, and deploy a service that will automatically classify future written requests into one of the categories. How should you configure the pipeline?

You need to quickly build and train a model to predict the sentiment of customer reviews with custom categories without writing code. You do not have enough data to train a model from scratch. The resulting model should have high predictive performance. Which service should you use?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
You do not have enough data to train a model from scratch. AutoML needs training data.

Selected Answer: A
custom modeling needed

Selected Answer: A
A) AutoML - Codeless
"Quickly build" >> usually go with the low-code/no-code options of autoML

Selected Answer: B
AutoML does not have transfer learning capabilities as of now. Given that there are
 not enough data to train from scratch, B is the only option that makes sense.

comments.content: AutoML now supports Transfer learning, I checked it.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
This suitable job for AutoML, it used transfer learning when there is small data for training.

Selected Answer: A
AutoML Natural Language is designed to work well even with relatively small datasets. It uses transfer learning and other techniques to train models effectively on limited data, which is crucial since there's enough data to train a model from scratch.

Selected Answer: A
Custom models and custom categories and hence AutoML natural language, It would still work with less data

Selected Answer: B
NO DATA TO TRAIN THE MODEL FROM SCRACH

comments.content: "You do not have enough data to train a model from scratch" - I think this means that there is SOME data but not a lot, something which AutoML can handle.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
Went with A

Selected Answer: A
It's A. "Custom categories" means B can't be correct

Its A, Check this document, https://cloud.google.com/natural-language/automl/docs/beginners-guide
The Natural Language API discovers syntax, entities, and sentiment in text, and classifies text into a predefined set of categories.

Selected Answer: B
If you do not have enough data to train a model from scratch, then it may be more appropriate to use a pre-trained model or a pre-made Jupyter Notebook.

Option B, the Cloud Natural Language API, could still be a viable option if you have access to labeled data for sentiment analysis. The API provides pre-trained models for sentiment analysis that you can use to classify text. However, if you have custom categories or labels, then you would need to train a custom model, which may not be feasible with limited data.

Selected Answer: A

In this case need custom categories without writing code

==> A

ans: A

B => "custom categories" so discarded.
C, D => discarded because "without writing code" and "do not have enough data".

A => AutoML can train with very little data ("The bare minimum required by AutoML Natural Language for training is 10 text examples per category/label"), as seifou says it will probably use transfer learning behind the scenes.

A is a correct. AutoML Natural Language can be trained on a few data. https://cloud.google.com/natural-language/automl/docs/beginners-guide#include-enough-labeled-examples-in-each-category. i think using transfer learning but I couldn't find any official document about it
A is correct. Natural Language AI is now part of Vertex AI -AutoML
